Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: The office buzzes with tension as the clock ticks toward the end of the quarter. My manager’s reminders echo in my mind: “We need three more sales, or we all lose our bonuses.” I stare at my call list, dialing number after number, my voice growing hoarse, my nerves fraying. Every rejection stings sharper tonight. But as the sun dips below the horizon, my phone vibrates with a message from the mosque: “Study circle at 8. We’ll discuss Surah Al-Baqarah, verses 30-50.” My heart sinks. I haven’t read those verses yet, let alone reflected on them. I know the expectation—come prepared, engage deeply, honor the Quran. But the sales target looms, and my team is counting on me. I glance at the Quran on my desk, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. My mind races: stay and call, or go and recite? The pressure mounts, and I feel torn, caught between the demands of my faith and the relentless push of my job.
